 4000: 
 4001:                             Preamble
 4002: 
 4003:   The GNU General Public License is a free, copyleft license for
 4004: software and other kinds of works.
 4005: 
 4006:   The licenses for most software and other practical works are designed
 4007: to take away your freedom to share and change the works.  By contrast,
 4008: the GNU General Public License is intended to guarantee your freedom to
 4009: share and change all versions of a program--to make sure it remains free
 4010: software for all its users.  We, the Free Software Foundation, use the
 4011: GNU General Public License for most of our software; it applies also to
 4012: any other work released this way by its authors.  You can apply it to
 4013: your programs, too.
 4014: 
 4015:   When we speak of free software, we are referring to freedom, not
 4016: price.  Our General Public Licenses are designed to make sure that you
 4017: have the freedom to distribute copies of free software (and charge for
 4018: them if you wish), that you receive source code or can get it if you
 4019: want it, that you can change the software or use pieces of it in new
 4020: free programs, and that you know you can do these things.
 4021: 
 4022:   To protect your rights, we need to prevent others from denying you
 4023: these rights or asking you to surrender the rights.  Therefore, you have
 4024: certain responsibilities if you distribute copies of the software, or if
 4025: you modify it: responsibilities to respect the freedom of others.
 4026: 
 4027:   For example, if you distribute copies of such a program, whether
 4028: gratis or for a fee, you must pass on to the recipients the same
 4029: freedoms that you received.  You must make sure that they, too, receive
 4030: or can get the source code.  And you must show them these terms so they
 4031: know their rights.
 4032: 
 4033:   Developers that use the GNU GPL protect your rights with two steps:
 4034: (1) assert copyright on the software, and (2) offer you this License
 4035: giving you legal permission to copy, distribute and/or modify it.
 4036: 
 4037:   For the developers' and authors' protection, the GPL clearly explains
 4038: that there is no warranty for this free software.  For both users' and
 4039: authors' sake, the GPL requires that modified versions be marked as
 4040: changed, so that their problems will not be attributed erroneously to
 4041: authors of previous versions.
 4042: 
 4043:   Some devices are designed to deny users access to install or run
 4044: modified versions of the software inside them, although the manufacturer
 4045: can do so.  This is fundamentally incompatible with the aim of
 4046: protecting users' freedom to change the software.  The systematic
 4047: pattern of such abuse occurs in the area of products for individuals to
 4048: use, which is precisely where it is most unacceptable.  Therefore, we
 4049: have designed this version of the GPL to prohibit the practice for those
 4050: products.  If such problems arise substantially in other domains, we
 4051: stand ready to extend this provision to those domains in future versions
 4052: of the GPL, as needed to protect the freedom of users.
 4053: 
 4054:   Finally, every program is threatened constantly by software patents.
 4055: States should not allow patents to restrict development and use of
 4056: software on general-purpose computers, but in those that do, we wish to
 4057: avoid the special danger that patents applied to a free program could
 4058: make it effectively proprietary.  To prevent this, the GPL assures that
 4059: patents cannot be used to render the program non-free.
 4060: 
 4061:   The precise terms and conditions for copying, distribution and
 4062: modification follow.
 4063: 
 4064:                        TERMS AND CONDITIONS
 4065: 
 4066:   0. Definitions.
 4067: 
 4068:   "This License" refers to version 3 of the GNU General Public License.
 4069: 
 4070:   "Copyright" also means copyright-like laws that apply to other kinds of
 4071: works, such as semiconductor masks.
 4072: 
 4073:   "The Program" refers to any copyrightable work licensed under this
 4074: License.  Each licensee is addressed as "you".  "Licensees" and
 4075: "recipients" may be individuals or organizations.
 4076: 
 4077:   To "modify" a work means to copy from or adapt all or part of the work
 4078: in a fashion requiring copyright permission, other than the making of an
 4079: exact copy.  The resulting work is called a "modified version" of the
 4080: earlier work or a work "based on" the earlier work.
 4081: 
 4082:   A "covered work" means either the unmodified Program or a work based
 4083: on the Program.
 4084: 
 4085:   To "propagate" a work means to do anything with it that, without
 4086: permission, would make you directly or secondarily liable for
 4087: infringement under applicable copyright law, except executing it on a
 4088: computer or modifying a private copy.  Propagation includes copying,
 4089: distribution (with or without modification), making available to the
 4090: public, and in some countries other activities as well.
 4091: 
 4092:   To "convey" a work means any kind of propagation that enables other
 4093: parties to make or receive copies.  Mere interaction with a user through
 4094: a computer network, with no transfer of a copy, is not conveying.
 4095: 
 4096:   An interactive user interface displays "Appropriate Legal Notices"
 4097: to the extent that it includes a convenient and prominently visible
 4098: feature that (1) displays an appropriate copyright notice, and (2)
 4099: tells the user that there is no warranty for the work (except to the
 4100: extent that warranties are provided), that licensees may convey the
 4101: work under this License, and how to view a copy of this License.  If
 4102: the interface presents a list of user commands or options, such as a
 4103: menu, a prominent item in the list meets this criterion.
 4104: 
 4105:   1. Source Code.
 4106: 
 4107:   The "source code" for a work means the preferred form of the work
 4108: for making modifications to it.  "Object code" means any non-source
 4109: form of a work.
 4110: 
 4111:   A "Standard Interface" means an interface that either is an official
 4112: standard defined by a recognized standards body, or, in the case of
 4113: interfaces specified for a particular programming language, one that
 4114: is widely used among developers working in that language.
 4115: 
 4116:   The "System Libraries" of an executable work include anything, other
 4117: than the work as a whole, that (a) is included in the normal form of
 4118: packaging a Major Component, but which is not part of that Major
 4119: Component, and (b) serves only to enable use of the work with that
 4120: Major Component, or to implement a Standard Interface for which an
 4121: implementation is available to the public in source code form.  A
 4122: "Major Component", in this context, means a major essential component
 4123: (kernel, window system, and so on) of the specific operating system
 4124: (if any) on which the executable work runs, or a compiler used to
 4125: produce the work, or an object code interpreter used to run it.
 4126: 
 4127:   The "Corresponding Source" for a work in object code form means all
 4128: the source code needed to generate, install, and (for an executable
 4129: work) run the object code and to modify the work, including scripts to
 4130: control those activities.  However, it does not include the work's
 4131: System Libraries, or general-purpose tools or generally available free
 4132: programs which are used unmodified in performing those activities but
 4133: which are not part of the work.  For example, Corresponding Source
 4134: includes interface definition files associated with source files for
 4135: the work, and the source code for shared libraries and dynamically
 4136: linked subprograms that the work is specifically designed to require,
 4137: such as by intimate data communication or control flow between those
 4138: subprograms and other parts of the work.
 4139: 
 4140:   The Corresponding Source need not include anything that users
 4141: can regenerate automatically from other parts of the Corresponding
 4142: Source.
 4143: 
 4144:   The Corresponding Source for a work in source code form is that
 4145: same work.
 4146: 
 4147:   2. Basic Permissions.
 4148: 
 4149:   All rights granted under this License are granted for the term of
 4150: copyright on the Program, and are irrevocable provided the stated
 4151: conditions are met.  This License explicitly affirms your unlimited
 4152: permission to run the unmodified Program.  The output from running a
 4153: covered work is covered by this License only if the output, given its
 4154: content, constitutes a covered work.  This License acknowledges your
 4155: rights of fair use or other equivalent, as provided by copyright law.
 4156: 
 4157:   You may make, run and propagate covered works that you do not
 4158: convey, without conditions so long as your license otherwise remains
 4159: in force.  You may convey covered works to others for the sole purpose
 4160: of having them make modifications exclusively for you, or provide you
 4161: with facilities for running those works, provided that you comply with
 4162: the terms of this License in conveying all material for which you do
 4163: not control copyright.  Those thus making or running the covered works
 4164: for you must do so exclusively on your behalf, under your direction
 4165: and control, on terms that prohibit them from making any copies of
 4166: your copyrighted material outside their relationship with you.
 4167: 
 4168:   Conveying under any other circumstances is permitted solely under
 4169: the conditions stated below.  Sublicensing is not allowed; section 10
 4170: makes it unnecessary.
 4171: 
 4172:   3. Protecting Users' Legal Rights From Anti-Circumvention Law.
 4173: 
 4174:   No covered work shall be deemed part of an effective technological
 4175: measure under any applicable law fulfilling obligations under article
 4176: 11 of the WIPO copyright treaty adopted on 20 December 1996, or
 4177: similar laws prohibiting or restricting circumvention of such
 4178: measures.
 4179: 
 4180:   When you convey a covered work, you waive any legal power to forbid
 4181: circumvention of technological measures to the extent such circumvention
 4182: is effected by exercising rights under this License with respect to
 4183: the covered work, and you disclaim any intention to limit operation or
 4184: modification of the work as a means of enforcing, against the work's
 4185: users, your or third parties' legal rights to forbid circumvention of
 4186: technological measures.
 4187: 
 4188:   4. Conveying Verbatim Copies.
 4189: 
 4190:   You may convey verbatim copies of the Program's source code as you
 4191: receive it, in any medium, provided that you conspicuously and
 4192: appropriately publish on each copy an appropriate copyright notice;
 4193: keep intact all notices stating that this License and any
 4194: non-permissive terms added in accord with section 7 apply to the code;
 4195: keep intact all notices of the absence of any warranty; and give all
 4196: recipients a copy of this License along with the Program.
 4197: 
 4198:   You may charge any price or no price for each copy that you convey,
 4199: and you may offer support or warranty protection for a fee.
 4200: 
 4201:   5. Conveying Modified Source Versions.
 4202: 
 4203:   You may convey a work based on the Program, or the modifications to
 4204: produce it from the Program, in the form of source code under the
 4205: terms of section 4, provided that you also meet all of these conditions:
 4206: 
 4207:     a) The work must carry prominent notices stating that you modified
 4208:     it, and giving a relevant date.
 4209: 
 4210:     b) The work must carry prominent notices stating that it is
 4211:     released under this License and any conditions added under section
 4212:     7.  This requirement modifies the requirement in section 4 to
 4213:     "keep intact all notices".
 4214: 
 4215:     c) You must license the entire work, as a whole, under this
 4216:     License to anyone who comes into possession of a copy.  This
 4217:     License will therefore apply, along with any applicable section 7
 4218:     additional terms, to the whole of the work, and all its parts,
 4219:     regardless of how they are packaged.  This License gives no
 4220:     permission to license the work in any other way, but it does not
 4221:     invalidate such permission if you have separately received it.
 4222: 
 4223:     d) If the work has interactive user interfaces, each must display
 4224:     Appropriate Legal Notices; however, if the Program has interactive
 4225:     interfaces that do not display Appropriate Legal Notices, your
 4226:     work need not make them do so.
 4227: 
 4228:   A compilation of a covered work with other separate and independent
 4229: works, which are not by their nature extensions of the covered work,
 4230: and which are not combined with it such as to form a larger program,
 4231: in or on a volume of a storage or distribution medium, is called an
 4232: "aggregate" if the compilation and its resulting copyright are not
 4233: used to limit the access or legal rights of the compilation's users
 4234: beyond what the individual works permit.  Inclusion of a covered work
 4235: in an aggregate does not cause this License to apply to the other
 4236: parts of the aggregate.
 4237: 
 4238:   6. Conveying Non-Source Forms.
 4239: 
 4240:   You may convey a covered work in object code form under the terms
 4241: of sections 4 and 5, provided that you also convey the
 4242: machine-readable Corresponding Source under the terms of this License,
 4243: in one of these ways:
 4244: 
 4245:     a) Convey the object code in, or embodied in, a physical product
 4246:     (including a physical distribution medium), accompanied by the
 4247:     Corresponding Source fixed on a durable physical medium
 4248:     customarily used for software interchange.
 4249: 
 4250:     b) Convey the object code in, or embodied in, a physical product
 4251:     (including a physical distribution medium), accompanied by a
 4252:     written offer, valid for at least three years and valid for as
 4253:     long as you offer spare parts or customer support for that product
 4254:     model, to give anyone who possesses the object code either (1) a
 4255:     copy of the Corresponding Source for all the software in the
 4256:     product that is covered by this License, on a durable physical
 4257:     medium customarily used for software interchange, for a price no
 4258:     more than your reasonable cost of physically performing this
 4259:     conveying of source, or (2) access to copy the
 4260:     Corresponding Source from a network server at no charge.
 4261: 
 4262:     c) Convey individual copies of the object code with a copy of the
 4263:     written offer to provide the Corresponding Source.  This
 4264:     alternative is allowed only occasionally and noncommercially, and
 4265:     only if you received the object code with such an offer, in accord
 4266:     with subsection 6b.
 4267: 
 4268:     d) Convey the object code by offering access from a designated
 4269:     place (gratis or for a charge), and offer equivalent access to the
 4270:     Corresponding Source in the same way through the same place at no
 4271:     further charge.  You need not require recipients to copy the
 4272:     Corresponding Source along with the object code.  If the place to
 4273:     copy the object code is a network server, the Corresponding Source
 4274:     may be on a different server (operated by you or a third party)
 4275:     that supports equivalent copying facilities, provided you maintain
 4276:     clear directions next to the object code saying where to find the
 4277:     Corresponding Source.  Regardless of what server hosts the
 4278:     Corresponding Source, you remain obligated to ensure that it is
 4279:     available for as long as needed to satisfy these requirements.
 4280: 
 4281:     e) Convey the object code using peer-to-peer transmission, provided
 4282:     you inform other peers where the object code and Corresponding
 4283:     Source of the work are being offered to the general public at no
 4284:     charge under subsection 6d.
 4285: 
 4286:   A separable portion of the object code, whose source code is excluded
 4287: from the Corresponding Source as a System Library, need not be
 4288: included in conveying the object code work.
 4289: 
 4290:   A "User Product" is either (1) a "consumer product", which means any
 4291: tangible personal property which is normally used for personal, family,
 4292: or household purposes, or (2) anything designed or sold for incorporation
 4293: into a dwelling.  In determining whether a product is a consumer product,
 4294: doubtful cases shall be resolved in favor of coverage.  For a particular
 4295: product received by a particular user, "normally used" refers to a
 4296: typical or common use of that class of product, regardless of the status
 4297: of the particular user or of the way in which the particular user
 4298: actually uses, or expects or is expected to use, the product.  A product
 4299: is a consumer product regardless of whether the product has substantial
 4300: commercial, industrial or non-consumer uses, unless such uses represent
 4301: the only significant mode of use of the product.
 4302: 
 4303:   "Installation Information" for a User Product means any methods,
 4304: procedures, authorization keys, or other information required to install
 4305: and execute modified versions of a covered work in that User Product from
 4306: a modified version of its Corresponding Source.  The information must
 4307: suffice to ensure that the continued functioning of the modified object
 4308: code is in no case prevented or interfered with solely because
 4309: modification has been made.
 4310: 
 4311:   If you convey an object code work under this section in, or with, or
 4312: specifically for use in, a User Product, and the conveying occurs as
 4313: part of a transaction in which the right of possession and use of the
 4314: User Product is transferred to the recipient in perpetuity or for a
 4315: fixed term (regardless of how the transaction is characterized), the
 4316: Corresponding Source conveyed under this section must be accompanied
 4317: by the Installation Information.  But this requirement does not apply
 4318: if neither you nor any third party retains the ability to install
 4319: modified object code on the User Product (for example, the work has
 4320: been installed in ROM).
 4321: 
 4322:   The requirement to provide Installation Information does not include a
 4323: requirement to continue to provide support service, warranty, or updates
 4324: for a work that has been modified or installed by the recipient, or for
 4325: the User Product in which it has been modified or installed.  Access to a
 4326: network may be denied when the modification itself materially and
 4327: adversely affects the operation of the network or violates the rules and
 4328: protocols for communication across the network.
 4329: 
 4330:   Corresponding Source conveyed, and Installation Information provided,
 4331: in accord with this section must be in a format that is publicly
 4332: documented (and with an implementation available to the public in
 4333: source code form), and must require no special password or key for
 4334: unpacking, reading or copying.
 4335: 
 4336:   7. Additional Terms.
 4337: 
 4338:   "Additional permissions" are terms that supplement the terms of this
 4339: License by making exceptions from one or more of its conditions.
 4340: Additional permissions that are applicable to the entire Program shall
 4341: be treated as though they were included in this License, to the extent
 4342: that they are valid under applicable law.  If additional permissions
 4343: apply only to part of the Program, that part may be used separately
 4344: under those permissions, but the entire Program remains governed by
 4345: this License without regard to the additional permissions.
 4346: 
 4347:   When you convey a copy of a covered work, you may at your option
 4348: remove any additional permissions from that copy, or from any part of
 4349: it.  (Additional permissions may be written to require their own
 4350: removal in certain cases when you modify the work.)  You may place
 4351: additional permissions on material, added by you to a covered work,
 4352: for which you have or can give appropriate copyright permission.
 4353: 
 4354:   Notwithstanding any other provision of this License, for material you
 4355: add to a covered work, you may (if authorized by the copyright holders of
 4356: that material) supplement the terms of this License with terms:
 4357: 
 4358:     a) Disclaiming warranty or limiting liability differently from the
 4359:     terms of sections 15 and 16 of this License; or
 4360: 
 4361:     b) Requiring preservation of specified reasonable legal notices or
 4362:     author attributions in that material or in the Appropriate Legal
 4363:     Notices displayed by works containing it; or
 4364: 
 4365:     c) Prohibiting misrepresentation of the origin of that material, or
 4366:     requiring that modified versions of such material be marked in
 4367:     reasonable ways as different from the original version; or
 4368: 
 4369:     d) Limiting the use for publicity purposes of names of licensors or
 4370:     authors of the material; or
 4371: 
 4372:     e) Declining to grant rights under trademark law for use of some
 4373:     trade names, trademarks, or service marks; or
 4374: 
 4375:     f) Requiring indemnification of licensors and authors of that
 4376:     material by anyone who conveys the material (or modified versions of
 4377:     it) with contractual assumptions of liability to the recipient, for
 4378:     any liability that these contractual assumptions directly impose on
 4379:     those licensors and authors.
 4380: 
 4381:   All other non-permissive additional terms are considered "further
 4382: restrictions" within the meaning of section 10.  If the Program as you
 4383: received it, or any part of it, contains a notice stating that it is
 4384: governed by this License along with a term that is a further
 4385: restriction, you may remove that term.  If a license document contains
 4386: a further restriction but permits relicensing or conveying under this
 4387: License, you may add to a covered work material governed by the terms
 4388: of that license document, provided that the further restriction does
 4389: not survive such relicensing or conveying.
 4390: 
 4391:   If you add terms to a covered work in accord with this section, you
 4392: must place, in the relevant source files, a statement of the
 4393: additional terms that apply to those files, or a notice indicating
 4394: where to find the applicable terms.
 4395: 
 4396:   Additional terms, permissive or non-permissive, may be stated in the
 4397: form of a separately written license, or stated as exceptions;
 4398: the above requirements apply either way.
 4399: 
 4400:   8. Termination.
 4401: 
 4402:   You may not propagate or modify a covered work except as expressly
 4403: provided under this License.  Any attempt otherwise to propagate or
 4404: modify it is void, and will automatically terminate your rights under
 4405: this License (including any patent licenses granted under the third
 4406: paragraph of section 11).
 4407: 
 4408:   However, if you cease all violation of this License, then your
 4409: license from a particular copyright holder is reinstated (a)
 4410: provisionally, unless and until the copyright holder explicitly and
 4411: finally terminates your license, and (b) permanently, if the copyright
 4412: holder fails to notify you of the violation by some reasonable means
 4413: prior to 60 days after the cessation.
 4414: 
 4415:   Moreover, your license from a particular copyright holder is
 4416: reinstated permanently if the copyright holder notifies you of the
 4417: violation by some reasonable means, this is the first time you have
 4418: received notice of violation of this License (for any work) from that
 4419: copyright holder, and you cure the violation prior to 30 days after
 4420: your receipt of the notice.
 4421: 
 4422:   Termination of your rights under this section does not terminate the
 4423: licenses of parties who have received copies or rights from you under
 4424: this License.  If your rights have been terminated and not permanently
 4425: reinstated, you do not qualify to receive new licenses for the same
 4426: material under section 10.
 4427: 
 4428:   9. Acceptance Not Required for Having Copies.
 4429: 
 4430:   You are not required to accept this License in order to receive or
 4431: run a copy of the Program.  Ancillary propagation of a covered work
 4432: occurring solely as a consequence of using peer-to-peer transmission
 4433: to receive a copy likewise does not require acceptance.  However,
 4434: nothing other than this License grants you permission to propagate or
 4435: modify any covered work.  These actions infringe copyright if you do
 4436: not accept this License.  Therefore, by modifying or propagating a
 4437: covered work, you indicate your acceptance of this License to do so.
 4438: 
 4439:   10. Automatic Licensing of Downstream Recipients.
 4440: 
 4441:   Each time you convey a covered work, the recipient automatically
 4442: receives a license from the original licensors, to run, modify and
 4443: propagate that work, subject to this License.  You are not responsible
 4444: for enforcing compliance by third parties with this License.
 4445: 
 4446:   An "entity transaction" is a transaction transferring control of an
 4447: organization, or substantially all assets of one, or subdividing an
 4448: organization, or merging organizations.  If propagation of a covered
 4449: work results from an entity transaction, each party to that
 4450: transaction who receives a copy of the work also receives whatever
 4451: licenses to the work the party's predecessor in interest had or could
 4452: give under the previous paragraph, plus a right to possession of the
 4453: Corresponding Source of the work from the predecessor in interest, if
 4454: the predecessor has it or can get it with reasonable efforts.
 4455: 
 4456:   You may not impose any further restrictions on the exercise of the
 4457: rights granted or affirmed under this License.  For example, you may
 4458: not impose a license fee, royalty, or other charge for exercise of
 4459: rights granted under this License, and you may not initiate litigation
 4460: (including a cross-claim or counterclaim in a lawsuit) alleging that
 4461: any patent claim is infringed by making, using, selling, offering for
 4462: sale, or importing the Program or any portion of it.
 4463: 
 4464:   11. Patents.
 4465: 
 4466:   A "contributor" is a copyright holder who authorizes use under this
 4467: License of the Program or a work on which the Program is based.  The
 4468: work thus licensed is called the contributor's "contributor version".
 4469: 
 4470:   A contributor's "essential patent claims" are all patent claims
 4471: owned or controlled by the contributor, whether already acquired or
 4472: hereafter acquired, that would be infringed by some manner, permitted
 4473: by this License, of making, using, or selling its contributor version,
 4474: but do not include claims that would be infringed only as a
 4475: consequence of further modification of the contributor version.  For
 4476: purposes of this definition, "control" includes the right to grant
 4477: patent sublicenses in a manner consistent with the requirements of
 4478: this License.
 4479: 
 4480:   Each contributor grants you a non-exclusive, worldwide, royalty-free
 4481: patent license under the contributor's essential patent claims, to
 4482: make, use, sell, offer for sale, import and otherwise run, modify and
 4483: propagate the contents of its contributor version.
 4484: 
 4485:   In the following three paragraphs, a "patent license" is any express
 4486: agreement or commitment, however denominated, not to enforce a patent
 4487: (such as an express permission to practice a patent or covenant not to
 4488: sue for patent infringement).  To "grant" such a patent license to a
 4489: party means to make such an agreement or commitment not to enforce a
 4490: patent against the party.
 4491: 
 4492:   If you convey a covered work, knowingly relying on a patent license,
 4493: and the Corresponding Source of the work is not available for anyone
 4494: to copy, free of charge and under the terms of this License, through a
 4495: publicly available network server or other readily accessible means,
 4496: then you must either (1) cause the Corresponding Source to be so
 4497: available, or (2) arrange to deprive yourself of the benefit of the
 4498: patent license for this particular work, or (3) arrange, in a manner
 4499: consistent with the requirements of this License, to extend the patent
 4500: license to downstream recipients.  "Knowingly relying" means you have
 4501: actual knowledge that, but for the patent license, your conveying the
 4502: covered work in a country, or your recipient's use of the covered work
 4503: in a country, would infringe one or more identifiable patents in that
 4504: country that you have reason to believe are valid.
 4505: 
 4506:   If, pursuant to or in connection with a single transaction or
 4507: arrangement, you convey, or propagate by procuring conveyance of, a
 4508: covered work, and grant a patent license to some of the parties
 4509: receiving the covered work authorizing them to use, propagate, modify
 4510: or convey a specific copy of the covered work, then the patent license
 4511: you grant is automatically extended to all recipients of the covered
 4512: work and works based on it.
 4513: 
 4514:   A patent license is "discriminatory" if it does not include within
 4515: the scope of its coverage, prohibits the exercise of, or is
 4516: conditioned on the non-exercise of one or more of the rights that are
 4517: specifically granted under this License.  You may not convey a covered
 4518: work if you are a party to an arrangement with a third party that is
 4519: in the business of distributing software, under which you make payment
 4520: to the third party based on the extent of your activity of conveying
 4521: the work, and under which the third party grants, to any of the
 4522: parties who would receive the covered work from you, a discriminatory
 4523: patent license (a) in connection with copies of the covered work
 4524: conveyed by you (or copies made from those copies), or (b) primarily
 4525: for and in connection with specific products or compilations that
 4526: contain the covered work, unless you entered into that arrangement,
 4527: or that patent license was granted, prior to 28 March 2007.
 4528: 
 4529:   Nothing in this License shall be construed as excluding or limiting
 4530: any implied license or other defenses to infringement that may
 4531: otherwise be available to you under applicable patent law.
 4532: 
 4533:   12. No Surrender of Others' Freedom.
 4534: 
 4535:   If conditions are imposed on you (whether by court order, agreement or
 4536: otherwise) that contradict the conditions of this License, they do not
 4537: excuse you from the conditions of this License.  If you cannot convey a
 4538: covered work so as to satisfy simultaneously your obligations under this
 4539: License and any other pertinent obligations, then as a consequence you may
 4540: not convey it at all.  For example, if you agree to terms that obligate you
 4541: to collect a royalty for further conveying from those to whom you convey
 4542: the Program, the only way you could satisfy both those terms and this
 4543: License would be to refrain entirely from conveying the Program.

 4571:

 4615: 
 4616:             How to Apply These Terms to Your New Programs
 4617: 
 4618:   If you develop a new program, and you want it to be of the greatest
 4619: possible use to the public, the best way to achieve this is to make it
 4620: free software which everyone can redistribute and change under these terms.
 4621: 
 4622:   To do so, attach the following notices to the program.  It is safest
 4623: to attach them to the start of each source file to most effectively
 4624: state the exclusion of warranty; and each file should have at least
 4625: the "copyright" line and a pointer to where the full notice is found.
 4626: 
 4627:     <one line to give the program's name and a brief idea of what it does.>
 4628:     Copyright (C) <year>  <name of author>
 4629: 
 4630:     This program is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify
 4631:     it under the terms of the GNU General Public License as published by
 4632:     the Free Software Foundation, either version 3 of the License, or
 4633:     (at your option) any later version.
 4634: 
 4635:     This program is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 4636:     but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 4637:     MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the
 4638:     GNU General Public License for more details.
 4639: 
 4640:     You should have received a copy of the GNU General Public License
 4641:     along with this program.  If not, see <https://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.
 4642: 
 4643: Also add information on how to contact you by electronic and paper mail.
 4644: 
 4645:   If the program does terminal interaction, make it output a short
 4646: notice like this when it starts in an interactive mode:
 4647: 
 4648:     <program>  Copyright (C) <year>  <name of author>
 4649:     This program comes with ABSOLUTELY NO WARRANTY; for details type `show w'.
 4650:     This is free software, and you are welcome to redistribute it
 4651:     under certain conditions; type `show c' for details.
 4652: 
 4653: The hypothetical commands `show w' and `show c' should show the appropriate
 4654: parts of the General Public License.  Of course, your program's commands
 4655: might be different; for a GUI interface, you would use an "about box".
 4656: 
 4657:   You should also get your employer (if you work as a programmer) or school,
 4658: if any, to sign a "copyright disclaimer" for the program, if necessary.
 4659: For more information on this, and how to apply and follow the GNU GPL, see
 4660: <https://www.gnu.org/licenses/>.
 4661: 
 4662:   The GNU General Public License does not permit incorporating your program
 4663: into proprietary programs.  If your program is a subroutine library, you
 4664: may consider it more useful to permit linking proprietary applications with
 4665: the library.  If this is what you want to do, use the GNU Lesser General
 4666: Public License instead of this License.  But first, please read
 4667: <https://www.gnu.org/licenses/why-not-lgpl.html>.

 4704: 
 4705:                             Preamble
 4706: 
 4707:   The licenses for most software are designed to take away your
 4708: freedom to share and change it.  By contrast, the GNU General Public
 4709: Licenses are intended to guarantee your freedom to share and change
 4710: free software--to make sure the software is free for all its users.
 4711: 
 4712:   This license, the Lesser General Public License, applies to some
 4713: specially designated software packages--typically libraries--of the
 4714: Free Software Foundation and other authors who decide to use it.  You
 4715: can use it too, but we suggest you first think carefully about whether
 4716: this license or the ordinary General Public License is the better
 4717: strategy to use in any particular case, based on the explanations below.
 4718: 
 4719:   When we speak of free software, we are referring to freedom of use,
 4720: not price.  Our General Public Licenses are designed to make sure that
 4721: you have the freedom to distribute copies of free software (and charge
 4722: for this service if you wish); that you receive source code or can get
 4723: it if you want it; that you can change the software and use pieces of
 4724: it in new free programs; and that you are informed that you can do
 4725: these things.
 4726: 
 4727:   To protect your rights, we need to make restrictions that forbid
 4728: distributors to deny you these rights or to ask you to surrender these
 4729: rights.  These restrictions translate to certain responsibilities for
 4730: you if you distribute copies of the library or if you modify it.
 4731: 
 4732:   For example, if you distribute copies of the library, whether gratis
 4733: or for a fee, you must give the recipients all the rights that we gave
 4734: you.  You must make sure that they, too, receive or can get the source
 4735: code.  If you link other code with the library, you must provide
 4736: complete object files to the recipients, so that they can relink them
 4737: with the library after making changes to the library and recompiling
 4738: it.  And you must show them these terms so they know their rights.
 4739: 
 4740:   We protect your rights with a two-step method: (1) we copyright the
 4741: library, and (2) we offer you this license, which gives you legal
 4742: permission to copy, distribute and/or modify the library.
 4743: 
 4744:   To protect each distributor, we want to make it very clear that
 4745: there is no warranty for the free library.  Also, if the library is
 4746: modified by someone else and passed on, the recipients should know
 4747: that what they have is not the original version, so that the original
 4748: author's reputation will not be affected by problems that might be
 4749: introduced by others.
 4750: 
 4751:   Finally, software patents pose a constant threat to the existence of
 4752: any free program.  We wish to make sure that a company cannot
 4753: effectively restrict the users of a free program by obtaining a
 4754: restrictive license from a patent holder.  Therefore, we insist that
 4755: any patent license obtained for a version of the library must be
 4756: consistent with the full freedom of use specified in this license.
 4757: 
 4758:   Most GNU software, including some libraries, is covered by the
 4759: ordinary GNU General Public License.  This license, the GNU Lesser
 4760: General Public License, applies to certain designated libraries, and
 4761: is quite different from the ordinary General Public License.  We use
 4762: this license for certain libraries in order to permit linking those
 4763: libraries into non-free programs.
 4764: 
 4765:   When a program is linked with a library, whether statically or using
 4766: a shared library, the combination of the two is legally speaking a
 4767: combined work, a derivative of the original library.  The ordinary
 4768: General Public License therefore permits such linking only if the
 4769: entire combination fits its criteria of freedom.  The Lesser General
 4770: Public License permits more lax criteria for linking other code with
 4771: the library.
 4772: 
 4773:   We call this license the "Lesser" General Public License because it
 4774: does Less to protect the user's freedom than the ordinary General
 4775: Public License.  It also provides other free software developers Less
 4776: of an advantage over competing non-free programs.  These disadvantages
 4777: are the reason we use the ordinary General Public License for many
 4778: libraries.  However, the Lesser license provides advantages in certain
 4779: special circumstances.
 4780: 
 4781:   For example, on rare occasions, there may be a special need to
 4782: encourage the widest possible use of a certain library, so that it becomes
 4783: a de-facto standard.  To achieve this, non-free programs must be
 4784: allowed to use the library.  A more frequent case is that a free
 4785: library does the same job as widely used non-free libraries.  In this
 4786: case, there is little to gain by limiting the free library to free
 4787: software only, so we use the Lesser General Public License.
 4788: 
 4789:   In other cases, permission to use a particular library in non-free
 4790: programs enables a greater number of people to use a large body of
 4791: free software.  For example, permission to use the GNU C Library in
 4792: non-free programs enables many more people to use the whole GNU
 4793: operating system, as well as its variant, the GNU/Linux operating
 4794: system.
 4795: 
 4796:   Although the Lesser General Public License is Less protective of the
 4797: users' freedom, it does ensure that the user of a program that is
 4798: linked with the Library has the freedom and the wherewithal to run
 4799: that program using a modified version of the Library.
 4800: 
 4801:   The precise terms and conditions for copying, distribution and
 4802: modification follow.  Pay close attention to the difference between a
 4803: "work based on the library" and a "work that uses the library".  The
 4804: former contains code derived from the library, whereas the latter must
 4805: be combined with the library in order to run.
 4806: 
 4807:                   GNU LESSER GENERAL PUBLIC LICENSE
 4808:    TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR COPYING, DISTRIBUTION AND MODIFICATION
 4809: 
 4810:   0. This License Agreement applies to any software library or other
 4811: program which contains a notice placed by the copyright holder or
 4812: other authorized party saying it may be distributed under the terms of
 4813: this Lesser General Public License (also called "this License").
 4814: Each licensee is addressed as "you".
 4815: 
 4816:   A "library" means a collection of software functions and/or data
 4817: prepared so as to be conveniently linked with application programs
 4818: (which use some of those functions and data) to form executables.
 4819: 
 4820:   The "Library", below, refers to any such software library or work
 4821: which has been distributed under these terms.  A "work based on the
 4822: Library" means either the Library or any derivative work under
 4823: copyright law: that is to say, a work containing the Library or a
 4824: portion of it, either verbatim or with modifications and/or translated
 4825: straightforwardly into another language.  (Hereinafter, translation is
 4826: included without limitation in the term "modification".)
 4827: 
 4828:   "Source code" for a work means the preferred form of the work for
 4829: making modifications to it.  For a library, complete source code means
 4830: all the source code for all modules it contains, plus any associated
 4831: interface definition files, plus the scripts used to control compilation
 4832: and installation of the library.
 4833: 
 4834:   Activities other than copying, distribution and modification are not
 4835: covered by this License; they are outside its scope.  The act of
 4836: running a program using the Library is not restricted, and output from
 4837: such a program is covered only if its contents constitute a work based
 4838: on the Library (independent of the use of the Library in a tool for
 4839: writing it).  Whether that is true depends on what the Library does
 4840: and what the program that uses the Library does.
 4841: 
 4842:   1. You may copy and distribute verbatim copies of the Library's
 4843: complete source code as you receive it, in any medium, provided that
 4844: you conspicuously and appropriately publish on each copy an
 4845: appropriate copyright notice and disclaimer of warranty; keep intact
 4846: all the notices that refer to this License and to the absence of any
 4847: warranty; and distribute a copy of this License along with the
 4848: Library.
 4849: 
 4850:   You may charge a fee for the physical act of transferring a copy,
 4851: and you may at your option offer warranty protection in exchange for a
 4852: fee.
 4853: 
 4854:   2. You may modify your copy or copies of the Library or any portion
 4855: of it, thus forming a work based on the Library, and copy and
 4856: distribute such modifications or work under the terms of Section 1
 4857: above, provided that you also meet all of these conditions:
 4858: 
 4859:     a) The modified work must itself be a software library.
 4860: 
 4861:     b) You must cause the files modified to carry prominent notices
 4862:     stating that you changed the files and the date of any change.
 4863: 
 4864:     c) You must cause the whole of the work to be licensed at no
 4865:     charge to all third parties under the terms of this License.
 4866: 
 4867:     d) If a facility in the modified Library refers to a function or a
 4868:     table of data to be supplied by an application program that uses
 4869:     the facility, other than as an argument passed when the facility
 4870:     is invoked, then you must make a good faith effort to ensure that,
 4871:     in the event an application does not supply such function or
 4872:     table, the facility still operates, and performs whatever part of
 4873:     its purpose remains meaningful.
 4874: 
 4875:     (For example, a function in a library to compute square roots has
 4876:     a purpose that is entirely well-defined independent of the
 4877:     application.  Therefore, Subsection 2d requires that any
 4878:     application-supplied function or table used by this function must
 4879:     be optional: if the application does not supply it, the square
 4880:     root function must still compute square roots.)
 4881: 
 4882: These requirements apply to the modified work as a whole.  If
 4883: identifiable sections of that work are not derived from the Library,
 4884: and can be reasonably considered independent and separate works in
 4885: themselves, then this License, and its terms, do not apply to those
 4886: sections when you distribute them as separate works.  But when you
 4887: distribute the same sections as part of a whole which is a work based
 4888: on the Library, the distribution of the whole must be on the terms of
 4889: this License, whose permissions for other licensees extend to the
 4890: entire whole, and thus to each and every part regardless of who wrote
 4891: it.
 4892: 
 4893: Thus, it is not the intent of this section to claim rights or contest
 4894: your rights to work written entirely by you; rather, the intent is to
 4895: exercise the right to control the distribution of derivative or
 4896: collective works based on the Library.
 4897: 
 4898: In addition, mere aggregation of another work not based on the Library
 4899: with the Library (or with a work based on the Library) on a volume of
 4900: a storage or distribution medium does not bring the other work under
 4901: the scope of this License.
 4902: 
 4903:   3. You may opt to apply the terms of the ordinary GNU General Public
 4904: License instead of this License to a given copy of the Library.  To do
 4905: this, you must alter all the notices that refer to this License, so
 4906: that they refer to the ordinary GNU General Public License, version 2,
 4907: instead of to this License.  (If a newer version than version 2 of the
 4908: ordinary GNU General Public License has appeared, then you can specify
 4909: that version instead if you wish.)  Do not make any other change in
 4910: these notices.
 4911: 
 4912:   Once this change is made in a given copy, it is irreversible for
 4913: that copy, so the ordinary GNU General Public License applies to all
 4914: subsequent copies and derivative works made from that copy.
 4915: 
 4916:   This option is useful when you wish to copy part of the code of
 4917: the Library into a program that is not a library.
 4918: 
 4919:   4. You may copy and distribute the Library (or a portion or
 4920: derivative of it, under Section 2) in object code or executable form
 4921: under the terms of Sections 1 and 2 above provided that you accompany
 4922: it with the complete corresponding machine-readable source code, which
 4923: must be distributed under the terms of Sections 1 and 2 above on a
 4924: medium customarily used for software interchange.
 4925: 
 4926:   If distribution of object code is made by offering access to copy
 4927: from a designated place, then offering equivalent access to copy the
 4928: source code from the same place satisfies the requirement to
 4929: distribute the source code, even though third parties are not
 4930: compelled to copy the source along with the object code.
 4931: 
 4932:   5. A program that contains no derivative of any portion of the
 4933: Library, but is designed to work with the Library by being compiled or
 4934: linked with it, is called a "work that uses the Library".  Such a
 4935: work, in isolation, is not a derivative work of the Library, and
 4936: therefore falls outside the scope of this License.
 4937: 
 4938:   However, linking a "work that uses the Library" with the Library
 4939: creates an executable that is a derivative of the Library (because it
 4940: contains portions of the Library), rather than a "work that uses the
 4941: library".  The executable is therefore covered by this License.
 4942: Section 6 states terms for distribution of such executables.
 4943: 
 4944:   When a "work that uses the Library" uses material from a header file
 4945: that is part of the Library, the object code for the work may be a
 4946: derivative work of the Library even though the source code is not.
 4947: Whether this is true is especially significant if the work can be
 4948: linked without the Library, or if the work is itself a library.  The
 4949: threshold for this to be true is not precisely defined by law.
 4950: 
 4951:   If such an object file uses only numerical parameters, data
 4952: structure layouts and accessors, and small macros and small inline
 4953: functions (ten lines or less in length), then the use of the object
 4954: file is unrestricted, regardless of whether it is legally a derivative
 4955: work.  (Executables containing this object code plus portions of the
 4956: Library will still fall under Section 6.)
 4957: 
 4958:   Otherwise, if the work is a derivative of the Library, you may
 4959: distribute the object code for the work under the terms of Section 6.
 4960: Any executables containing that work also fall under Section 6,
 4961: whether or not they are linked directly with the Library itself.
 4962: 
 4963:   6. As an exception to the Sections above, you may also combine or
 4964: link a "work that uses the Library" with the Library to produce a
 4965: work containing portions of the Library, and distribute that work
 4966: under terms of your choice, provided that the terms permit
 4967: modification of the work for the customer's own use and reverse
 4968: engineering for debugging such modifications.
 4969: 
 4970:   You must give prominent notice with each copy of the work that the
 4971: Library is used in it and that the Library and its use are covered by
 4972: this License.  You must supply a copy of this License.  If the work
 4973: during execution displays copyright notices, you must include the
 4974: copyright notice for the Library among them, as well as a reference
 4975: directing the user to the copy of this License.  Also, you must do one
 4976: of these things:
 4977: 
 4978:     a) Accompany the work with the complete corresponding
 4979:     machine-readable source code for the Library including whatever
 4980:     changes were used in the work (which must be distributed under
 4981:     Sections 1 and 2 above); and, if the work is an executable linked
 4982:     with the Library, with the complete machine-readable "work that
 4983:     uses the Library", as object code and/or source code, so that the
 4984:     user can modify the Library and then relink to produce a modified
 4985:     executable containing the modified Library.  (It is understood
 4986:     that the user who changes the contents of definitions files in the
 4987:     Library will not necessarily be able to recompile the application
 4988:     to use the modified definitions.)
 4989: 
 4990:     b) Use a suitable shared library mechanism for linking with the
 4991:     Library.  A suitable mechanism is one that (1) uses at run time a
 4992:     copy of the library already present on the user's computer system,
 4993:     rather than copying library functions into the executable, and (2)
 4994:     will operate properly with a modified version of the library, if
 4995:     the user installs one, as long as the modified version is
 4996:     interface-compatible with the version that the work was made with.
 4997: 
 4998:     c) Accompany the work with a written offer, valid for at
 4999:     least three years, to give the same user the materials
 5000:     specified in Subsection 6a, above, for a charge no more
 5001:     than the cost of performing this distribution.
 5002: 
 5003:     d) If distribution of the work is made by offering access to copy
 5004:     from a designated place, offer equivalent access to copy the above
 5005:     specified materials from the same place.
 5006: 
 5007:     e) Verify that the user has already received a copy of these
 5008:     materials or that you have already sent this user a copy.
 5009: 
 5010:   For an executable, the required form of the "work that uses the
 5011: Library" must include any data and utility programs needed for
 5012: reproducing the executable from it.  However, as a special exception,
 5013: the materials to be distributed need not include anything that is
 5014: normally distributed (in either source or binary form) with the major
 5015: components (compiler, kernel, and so on) of the operating system on
 5016: which the executable runs, unless that component itself accompanies
 5017: the executable.
 5018: 
 5019:   It may happen that this requirement contradicts the license
 5020: restrictions of other proprietary libraries that do not normally
 5021: accompany the operating system.  Such a contradiction means you cannot
 5022: use both them and the Library together in an executable that you
 5023: distribute.
 5024: 
 5025:   7. You may place library facilities that are a work based on the
 5026: Library side-by-side in a single library together with other library
 5027: facilities not covered by this License, and distribute such a combined
 5028: library, provided that the separate distribution of the work based on
 5029: the Library and of the other library facilities is otherwise
 5030: permitted, and provided that you do these two things:
 5031: 
 5032:     a) Accompany the combined library with a copy of the same work
 5033:     based on the Library, uncombined with any other library
 5034:     facilities.  This must be distributed under the terms of the
 5035:     Sections above.
 5036: 
 5037:     b) Give prominent notice with the combined library of the fact
 5038:     that part of it is a work based on the Library, and explaining
 5039:     where to find the accompanying uncombined form of the same work.
 5040: 
 5041:   8. You may not copy, modify, sublicense, link with, or distribute
 5042: the Library except as expressly provided under this License.  Any
 5043: attempt otherwise to copy, modify, sublicense, link with, or
 5044: distribute the Library is void, and will automatically terminate your
 5045: rights under this License.  However, parties who have received copies,
 5046: or rights, from you under this License will not have their licenses
 5047: terminated so long as such parties remain in full compliance.
 5048: 
 5049:   9. You are not required to accept this License, since you have not
 5050: signed it.  However, nothing else grants you permission to modify or
 5051: distribute the Library or its derivative works.  These actions are
 5052: prohibited by law if you do not accept this License.  Therefore, by
 5053: modifying or distributing the Library (or any work based on the
 5054: Library), you indicate your acceptance of this License to do so, and
 5055: all its terms and conditions for copying, distributing or modifying
 5056: the Library or works based on it.
 5057: 
 5058:   10. Each time you redistribute the Library (or any work based on the
 5059: Library), the recipient automatically receives a license from the
 5060: original licensor to copy, distribute, link with or modify the Library
 5061: subject to these terms and conditions.  You may not impose any further
 5062: restrictions on the recipients' exercise of the rights granted herein.
 5063: You are not responsible for enforcing compliance by third parties with
 5064: this License.
 5065: 
 5066:   11. If, as a consequence of a court judgment or allegation of patent
 5067: infringement or for any other reason (not limited to patent issues),
 5068: conditions are imposed on you (whether by court order, agreement or
 5069: otherwise) that contradict the conditions of this License, they do not
 5070: excuse you from the conditions of this License.  If you cannot
 5071: distribute so as to satisfy simultaneously your obligations under this
 5072: License and any other pertinent obligations, then as a consequence you
 5073: may not distribute the Library at all.  For example, if a patent
 5074: license would not permit royalty-free redistribution of the Library by
 5075: all those who receive copies directly or indirectly through you, then
 5076: the only way you could satisfy both it and this License would be to
 5077: refrain entirely from distribution of the Library.
 5078: 
 5079: If any portion of this section is held invalid or unenforceable under any
 5080: particular circumstance, the balance of the section is intended to apply,
 5081: and the section as a whole is intended to apply in other circumstances.
 5082: 
 5083: It is not the purpose of this section to induce you to infringe any
 5084: patents or other property right claims or to contest validity of any
 5085: such claims; this section has the sole purpose of protecting the
 5086: integrity of the free software distribution system which is
 5087: implemented by public license practices.  Many people have made
 5088: generous contributions to the wide range of software distributed
 5089: through that system in reliance on consistent application of that
 5090: system; it is up to the author/donor to decide if he or she is willing
 5091: to distribute software through any other system and a licensee cannot
 5092: impose that choice.
 5093: 
 5094: This section is intended to make thoroughly clear what is believed to
 5095: be a consequence of the rest of this License.

 5098: certain countries either by patents or by copyrighted interfaces, the

 5111: specifies a version number of this License which applies to it and
 5112: "any later version", you have the option of following the terms and

 5119: programs whose distribution conditions are incompatible with these,

 5124: of all derivatives of our free software and of promoting the sharing
 5125: and reuse of software generally.

 5132: OTHER PARTIES PROVIDE THE LIBRARY "AS IS" WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY

 5140: WRITING WILL ANY COPYRIGHT HOLDER, OR ANY OTHER PARTY WHO MAY MODIFY

 5142: FOR DAMAGES, INCLUDING ANY GENERAL, SPECIAL, INCIDENTAL OR
 5143: CONSEQUENTIAL DAMAGES ARISING OUT OF THE USE OR INABILITY TO USE THE
 5144: LIBRARY (INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO LOSS OF DATA OR DATA BEING

 5153: 
 5154:   If you develop a new library, and you want it to be of the greatest
 5155: possible use to the public, we recommend making it free software that
 5156: everyone can redistribute and change.  You can do so by permitting
 5157: redistribution under these terms (or, alternatively, under the terms of the
 5158: ordinary General Public License).
 5159: 
 5160:   To apply these terms, attach the following notices to the library.  It is
 5161: safest to attach them to the start of each source file to most effectively
 5162: convey the exclusion of warranty; and each file should have at least the
 5163: "copyright" line and a pointer to where the full notice is found.
 5164: 
 5165:     <one line to give the library's name and a brief idea of what it does.>
 5166:     Copyright (C) <year>  <name of author>
 5167: 
 5168:     This library is free software; you can redistribute it and/or
 5169:     modify it under the terms of the GNU Lesser General Public
 5170:     License as published by the Free Software Foundation; either
 5171:     version 2.1 of the License, or (at your option) any later version.
 5172: 
 5173:     This library is distributed in the hope that it will be useful,
 5174:     but WITHOUT ANY WARRANTY; without even the implied warranty of
 5175:     MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE.  See the GNU
 5176:     Lesser General Public License for more details.
 5177: 
 5178:     You should have received a copy of the GNU Lesser General Public
 5179:     License along with this library; if not, write to the Free Software
 5180:     Foundation, Inc., 51 Franklin Street, Fifth Floor, Boston, MA  02110-1301
 5181:     USA
 5182: 
 5183: Also add information on how to contact you by electronic and paper mail.
 5184: 
 5185: You should also get your employer (if you work as a programmer) or your
 5186: school, if any, to sign a "copyright disclaimer" for the library, if
 5187: necessary.  Here is a sample; alter the names:

 5190:   library `Frob' (a library for tweaking knobs) written by James Random
 5191:   Hacker.
